intro: Styphelia melaleucoides subsp. melaleucoides, commonly known as the white-stemmed snowbell, is a flowering plant native to the wet heathlands of southeastern Australia. It is a small, evergreen shrub that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm. The plant produces clusters of small, white, bell-shaped flowers during the spring and early summer. Its leaves are narrow, leathery, and arranged in a spiral pattern around the stems. It thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in coastal or near-coastal regions.
